title: Backyard Farming On An Acre {Book Review}

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
As you may or may not know, since I’ve mentioned it before on the blog, Mr. Nurture and I are in the process of saving up for our atypical dream house – a modest homestead with ample land to grow our own food, raise small farm animals, and live a truly sustainable lifestyle, closer to nature and closer to the way our ancestors lived.

I’ve been racking up (read hoarding) as many resources as I can get my hands on to prepare us for this journey, which is also part of the reason I started this blog in the first place. So I was really excited when Angela England, of Untrained Housewife, announced that she had a written a how-to guide on backyard farming, and offered me a copy to review!

Backyard Farming On An Acre (More Or Less) Review

Backyard Farming On An Acre (More or Less) is the ultimate guide for those wishing to eat healthier, save money, and live more sustainably. Whether you’re looking to purchase new farm land or to build on land you already own, Angela breaks everything down in an easy-to-follow, comprehensive way, explaining everything you need to know from zoning restrictions to water access.

Ready to start your edible gardening? Angela’s got you completely covered, with helpful tips and advice on planning, planting, raising, and harvesting everything from vegetables and herbs, to fruits, berries, and nuts! The book is really organized in such an easy format, you can just open the table of contents, find the plant you want to learn more about, then flip to the correct page to find information, pictures, and down-to-earth advice on all that goes into growing and harvesting that plant.

One of the most useful things for me, about this book, is the section on animal farming. This is an area which I’ve yet to learn much about, so Angela’s detailed, yet concise, instructions on buying and raising chickens, goats, sheep, and rabbits was just perfect! I learned more in the 20 minutes that it took me to look through that section than I ever could have learned by reading through online guides and forums! I’m so glad to have all this information in one place, to go back to and reference when I need it!

And ultimately, my favorite sections of the book are what Angela calls “Enjoying the Bounty” and “Crafting From the Backyard Farm.” If you’ve been following this blog for any amount of time, I’m sure you can guess why. 🙂 These sections are literally the “bread and butter” of the book, in my opinion. After all the hard work of planning, raising, and harvesting from your farm, the fruits of your labor can be  enjoyed through fresh, seasonal produce used in delicious recipes, or preserved (by canning, freezing, or dehydrating) in your root cellar. Want to learn to make cheese? How about harvesting your sheep’s fleece to turn into yarn? Or making handmade soap from your goat’s milk? All this and so much more is outlined so beautifully in the pages of this book.

This is not just a book, it’s much more than that. Honestly, it’s as if Angela is sitting across the table from you, teaching you all that she’s learned about backyard farming, in a fun, personal, conversational manner. Whether you’re looking to start your first small garden this year, or want to plan a full-fledged mini-farm on your property, Backyard Farming On An Acre (More Or Less) is the place to start!

Check out the Backyard Farming On An Acre website, as well as on Facebook!

Where to Buy Backyard Farming On An Acre

You can purchase Backyard Farming On An Acre (More Or Less) online at Amazon.com, and as of today, it’s on sale for only $13.60 (US) and qualifies for FREE Super Saver Shipping!

Also, from now until December 2oth (that’s tomorrow!), Angela will send you some amazing free bonuses with your purchase! We’re talking over $10 of bonuses, including a neat homeschool companion study guide for the book! Check out the details on this great offer here.

But you don’t have to wait until your copy arrives to start enjoying the wonderful resources this book has to offer – check out Angela’s downloadable resources page for free homesteading resources and printables to get you started on your way to a healthier, more sustainable lifestyle!

title: Natural Ways to Treat Nausea

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Peppermint Candy Image courtesy of Maggie Smith / FreeDigitalPhotos.net

Last week, Mr. Nurture wasn’t feeling too well, and I shared with you some natural ways to treat headaches. Well, along with his killer migraine came some really bad nausea as well! Thankfully, we treated it with some homemade ginger tea, but that didn’t stop me from doing more research and looking for even more natural ways to relieve and treat nausea!

 

Besides ginger in all its forms, the other top contender for treating nausea is undoubtedly peppermint. Either as a candy, a[amazon_link id=”B0009F3PJ4″ target=”_blank” ]tea[/amazon_link], or even an [amazon_link id=”B00028MKRQ” target=”_blank” ]essential oil[/amazon_link] used in aromatherapy, peppermint has been found to successfully treat the symptoms of nausea. It’s the menthol properties that have antispasmodic properties that help relieve the indigestion that comes along with nausea.

Looking for more natural ways to treat nausea? Head on over to the Healthy Planet blog to find out some of the other natural treatments for nausea, by clicking the link below!

title: Ditch The Plastic with Takeya Glass Water Bottles {Review}

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Are you ready to ditch those plastic water bottles once and for all? Seriously, you know you need to, but something keeps pulling you back. I know, because I spent the last few years on what I’ll refer to as my “water bottle journey.”

It goes a little something like this (No judgement, please. Some of this was before I became Mrs. Nurture 😉 ):

  • Bought and drank from plastic water bottles like no one’s business. All day, every day. Toss one, open the next.
  • Started at least recycling my used plastic bottles… that’s helping, right?!
  • Bought a reusable plastic water bottle… yay, I’m really doing my part now!
  • Bought a new, BPA-free plastic bottle… Oops, my last bottle wasn’t BPA free – but this one is!

And that brings me to now. Well, a couple months ago. That’s when I realized that even though my plastic water bottle was BPA-free, it was still plastic. Meaning that it was made from petroleum (a non-renewable resource), it had a very limited recyclable life (1 or 2 times, max!), and honestly, I was too afraid to ever put anything else in it, besides water – water is colorless and odorless. But iced teas? Smoothies? Milk shakes? Not so much. And the last thing I wanted to smell when I went to take a sip of my water next time, was anything other than water.

So I started doing some research and learned that buying a glass water bottle really wasn’t such a crazy idea after all. It sounds almost impossible, but there are a lot of glass water bottles on the market! A couple weeks ago, I was asked to review the Takeya glass water bottle, and seeing how I was in the market for one, I happily agreed. 🙂

About Takeya Glass Water Bottles

  • Bottle is FDA-approved glass. Sleeve is non-toxic silicone. Cap is BPA-free #5 polypropylene. Free of lead and phthalates.
  • Silicone sleeve for non-slip grip & protection.
  • See-through window helps you monitor your water intake.
  • Airtight twist cap with easy carry loop design.
  • Wide mouth for ice & easy cleaning
  • Dishwasher safe

Takeya Glass Water Bottles Review

Right off the bat, I just love the way Takeya glass water bottle looks – so sleek, so slim, and yet it still holds a sizable 22 ounces of liquid. The color is awesome; bright and fun and the color in the pictures is pretty true to life. The silicone also feels nice and smooth; not rough at all, but also not too slick so that it feels like it will slip out of my hand or anything.

The mouth is actually a perfect size – not too wide so that it’s hard to control the flow of water, but not too small either, since I can easily fit ice cubes inside, if I need to. It’s very easy to drink out of, and I think it’s actually helping me drink more water – go figure! I use a long bottle brush to clean my bottles and my brush fit nicely inside; it was a little snug, but it fit. The bottle is a little tall, but it’s slim so it’s not hefty at all. I really love the way it feels in my hand – not just the soft silicone sleeve, but even the width of the bottle seems the perfect size.

It’s dishwasher safe, but I haven’t put it in my dishwasher yet. I usually just hand wash and let it dry on the dish rack. The only thing that bothers me just a bit is that the silicone sleeve isn’t snug enough around the middle (where the see-through area is), so water can easily get behind the sleeve when you wash it. My main concern with this is if there’s a possibility for mold growth over time. Since I’ve only been using it for a few weeks, I guess time will only tell.

In the meantime, I definitely like these glass water bottles! I was hesitant to make the switch to glass, but after using one for several weeks, I can’t imagine ever going back to plastic water bottles. Even the water tastes better – crisp, clean, fresh – just the way nature intended. 🙂

Where To Buy Takeya Glass Water Bottles

Takeya glass water bottles can be purchased online at Reuseit.com for 19.95 (22 oz), and $17.95 (16 oz). They come in 5 gorgeous colors, pictured above. Shipping is a flat-rate of $4.95 and if you spend $49 or more, your order ships for FREE (Enter coupon code BELLS12 at checkout). Also, as a new customer, if you spend $25 or more, you’ll get a free gift!

So are you ready to make the switch to a safer, more eco-friendly water bottle?

I received one or more of the products mentioned above for free using Tomoson.com. Regardless, I only recommend products or services I use personally and believe will be good for my readers.

Thanks for partying with us every week at Tiny Tip Tuesday, and we’ll see you in 2013!

title: Natural Ways to Treat Headaches

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Image courtesy of m_bartosch / FreeDigitalPhotos.net

Headaches are such a pain (literally!) and can be so debilitating at times… Earlier this week, Mr. Nurture had a killer migraine along with some nausea for the better half of the morning. Right away I made him some ginger tea for the nausea (I remembered that from my pregnancy days!), but was stumped on what to do about the headache. We’d been out of the over-the-counter medications for a while now, and I really wanted to try some natural methods of treating this terrible headache he had.

I asked a few of my natural blogger friends, and Angela at Earth Faerie Momma and Amanda at Natural Living Mamma, immediately responded with the suggestion of using essential oils for the headache. Lavender and peppermint oils were suggested for their calming and soothing properties. I diluted a few drops of both [amazon_link id=”B002N0PY8S” target=”_blank” ]lavender[/amazon_link] and [amazon_link id=”B002N0MZMQ” target=”_blank” ]peppermint[/amazon_link] oils into a small amount of coconut oil, and rubbed it on his temples, neck and upper back. I also put a few drops of peppermint oil on a cotton ball and had him inhale it for a few minutes as he laid down for a nap.

Thankfully, by mid-afternoon, after a good nap, Mr. Nurture woke up feeling much better and refreshed! Natural remedies had successfully provided him some very much needed relief for his headache, so I became curious about more natural ways to treat headaches, since they’re such a common issue for many people. I found some more interesting remedies, including some very helpful prevention tips, which I’m sharing at the Healthy Planet blog today. Click the link below for the complete post!

All-Natural Headache Remedies

title: Immune Boosting Fire Cider For Cold & Flu Season

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
I’m so overwhelmed by the positive response to my natural sore throat and cough syrup post, that I’m continuing the cold and flu series with this lovely immune boosting fire cider recipe that I found on the Mountain Rose Herbs blog! 

I’d never heard of fire cider before, but apparently it’s an old folk remedy that’s been used during the cold, winter months as an immune-boosting, anti-viral, anti-bacterial, warming tonic. The ingredients can change from year to year, depending on what you have growing in your garden, but the basics stay the same: cider vinegar, onion, garlic, horseradish, ginger, and hot peppers.

The original recipe uses jalapeno peppers, but I didn’t have any on hand, so I used some powdered cayenne pepper instead. Cayenne was one of the star ingredients in my sore throat and cough syrup, so I knew it would be a great addition to this fire cider!

Some other herbs and spices were recommended as variations to the recipe, including thyme, ginseng, orange, and oregano, so I chose to also add some dried thyme to the mix since it has some great healing properties (see full ingredient properties below).

One thing you do need to know is that I haven’t actually tried this cider yet, because it has to be infused and extracted for a whole month before it’s ready to be used. Well, a month is just way too long for me to wait to post this awesome-looking recipe, so I’ve decided to share it with you in hopes that you’ll join me in making this now, so we can come back in a month and test it out together – just in time for the coldest winter days ahead!

UPDATE: Check out the update post to learn about the next steps in the process as well as how we’ve been using it in our home!

 

 
Immune-Boosting Cold-Fighting Fire Cider
2013-06-17 18:51:17
An immune-boosting, anti-bacterial, anti-viral tonic made with herbs and spices to help ward off or soothe colds and keep you warm during the cold, winter months.
Write a review
Save Recipe
Print
Ingredients
  1. 1/2 cup fresh grated ginger root
  2. 1/2 cup fresh grated horseradish root
  3. 1 medium onion, chopped
  4. 10 cloves of garlic, crushed
  5. Zest and juice from 1 lemon
  6. 2 teaspoons cayenne pepper
  7. 2 tablespoons of dried rosemary leaves
  8. 1 tablespoon dried thyme
  9. 1 tablespoon turmeric powder
  10. raw apple cider vinegar (with the "mother")
  11. raw honey to taste
Instructions
  1. Add the prepared herbs, spices, and lemon juice and zest to a quart-sized jar.
  2. Top off the jar with apple cider vinegar, leaving some room at the top for shaking the jar.
  3. Cover the jar, but place a piece of wax paper or parchment paper under the lid to keep the cider from touching the metal lid.
  4. Shake very well to get everything mixed together, then store in a cool, dry place (like a pantry or cupboard) for a month. Remember to shake the jar daily!
  5. After a month, strain out the pulp through a cheesecloth, pouring the cider into a clean jar. Squeeze out as much liquid from the pulp as possible.
  6. Add 1/4 cup honey to the strained cider and stir well. Taste the cider and, if needed, add more honey to reach desired sweetness.
Notes
  1. Take 1 tablespoon a day as a preventive measure, or 3 tablespoons at the first sign of a cold.
By Sarah @ Nature's Nurture
Adapted from Mountain Rose Herbs
Adapted from Mountain Rose Herbs
Nature's Nurture http://naturesnurtureblog.com/
Wordpress Recipe Plugin by Recipe Card
 
3.1.09

How To Use Fire Cider

According to the Mountain Rose Herbs blog, there are a whole bunch of great ways to use this cider during the winter months!

  • Take 1 tablespoon a day as a preventive measure, or 3 tablespoons at the first sign of a cold.
  • Add it to vegetable juice, or make a non-alcoholic bloody mary by adding some olives and pickles to the juice.
  • Splash it on fried rice.
  • Drizzle over a salad along with some olive oil.
  • Use the strained pulp (yay for no waste!) and add it to shredded veggies to make stir fries and spring rolls.

More About the Ingredients

This cider contains some of the most potent, healing herbs and spices. Here are some of their healing properties:

  • Ginger – anti-inflammatory, expectorant (relieves and suppresses coughing), and warms and energizes the body.
  • Horseradish – antibiotic, expectorant, bronchodilator (relaxes bronchial muscles), antibacterial, warms the body, anti-inflammatory, and stimulates the immune system.
  • Onion – antibiotic, anti-inflammatory, expectorant, and antioxidant.
  • Garlic – antiviral, antibacterial, antioxidant, and helps support the immune system.
  • Lemon – rich in vitamin C, detoxifier, anti-viral, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and helps bring down a fever.
  • Cayenne – reduces the sensation of pain, thins mucus, increases blood flow, and clears congestion.
  • Rosemary – antibacterial, anti-fungal, antiviral, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and analgesic (pain-killer).
  • Thyme – antibacterial, anti-fungal, antiseptic, expectorant, and warms the body.
  • Turmeric – antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant.
  • Apple Cider Vinegar – antibacterial, antiviral, antiseptic, and promotes healing.
  • Raw Honey – anti-viral, anti-bacterial, coats the throat, and contains beneficial enzymes to protect against infection.

title: My Favorite Vegetarian Sources for Protein

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Image courtesy of dan / FreeDigitalPhotos.net

Our family is not vegetarian, but we have been known to refer to ourselves as “semi-vegetarian” in that we don’t eat meat very often. Mainly because we don’t think we’re supposed to be eating meat as often as is now common in today’s society, but also because when we do eat meat, we like to make sure that it’s organic, ethically raised, pastured, and grass-fed (and bugs and insects for chickens! ;)). On top of all of that, since our family is Muslim, we also stick to a ‘halal’ diet, which is basically the Muslim version of kosher, and includes strict guidelines as to how an animal is raised, how it’s slaughtered, and how it’s handled afterwards. (Are you vegetarians still with me? or did I lose you at the ‘slaughtered’ part?)

That being said, when friends and family learn about how infrequently we eat meat, their inevitable first question is always, “but how will you get your protein?” And after speaking with (actual) vegetarians, I’ve realized just how common that question really is! If people only knew how plentiful protein actually is in non-meat-based sources, they would realize just how off-base that question really is!

The idea that protein only (or mostly) comes from meat is a myth that has plagued much of western society for decades, and has lead to inhumane, unsustainable practices such as factory farming that have taken over the food industry. The truth is that meat is a delicacy in most cultures around the world, only to be served and savored at the most special of occasions, not eaten at every single meal, every single day, of every single year, which has almost become the norm in the West. These cultures (which eat meat only occasionally), have been getting their protein from plant-based and other sources for centuries, and have lived to tell about it, so let’s get one thing clear: cutting meat from your diet will not deprive your body of protein, as long as you make sure to get your protein from other sources!

Our favorite vegetarian sources for protein (besides yummy green veggies, of course!) include beans and lentils, nuts and seeds, greek yogurt, and hemp powder. We love running the crock pot during these winter months and simmering some vegetarian chili with a whole rainbow of colorful beans. We also buy nuts and seeds in bulk and use them for snacking and making homemade nut butters! Greek yogurt is basically just a strained yogurt, so the protein content becomes concentrated. If you make homemade yogurt, you can just strain it in a cheesecloth overnight in the fridge until it’s the consistency you like. We also add a big scoop of hemp powder to our morning smoothies for a healthy protein kick to start our day!

There are a few other great sources for protein, which I’m sharing over at the Healthy Planet blog today, so click the link below to read the full list, along with their protein content and yummy ways to serve them up. I also share a super easy way to figure out your daily protein requirement!

title: Reusable Snack & Sandwich Bags from ReUsies {Review & Giveaway}

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Slowly, but surely, we’re trying to cut out plastic products from our home, and today I want to share with you something so simple, and yet so revolutionary, that we’ve discovered on this journey: reusable snack and sandwich bags!

My childhood schol lunch memories consist of brown paper bags, plastic zipper baggies, and juice boxes…all of which were nonchalantly thrown out at the end of lunch period, only to be replaced by new ones the next day – maddening, right?! But that’s exactly what’s still happening today in schools and workplaces across the country. Every single day, every day of the year…can you even imagine how many of those little plastic baggies are just sitting in landfills, or worse, in the ocean, never to decompose, forever plaguing the environment with their presence? So you can understand my excitement when I had the chance to try out these reusable snack and sandwich bags from ReUsies!

What Are ReUsies?

ReUsies are reusable snack and sandwich bags that can potentially keep hundreds, if not thousands, of plastic baggies out of the landfills and oceans. When I received my package in the mail, I was pleasantly surprised with how minimal the packaging was – right in line with their “less-waste” philosophy!

  • BPA-free and phthalates-free
  • made from 100% cotton, lined with a leak-resistant nylon layer, and use hook-and-loop closures
  • Machine-washable, dishwasher-safe, or for the longest life, simple hand-washing is recommended
  • available in two different sizes (sandwich and snack)
  • of different colors, prints, and patterns.

ReUsies Reusable Snack and Sandwich Bags Review

I was sent two bags (1 snack size, and 1 sandwich size) in this pretty love birds print. I couldn’t wait to start using them, so before heading out for our daily walk to the park, Monkey and I filled our new reusable bags with the snacks we wanted for our trip: sliced apples in the large bag, and almonds and graham crackers in the small bag. I really wanted to see if these bags would pass the “apple test” – keeping them from drying out and/or browning.

Surprisingly, these bags worked great for the apples; they didn’t brown any more than they would have had they been in a regular, plastic zipper baggie, which is great! Our other smaller snacks were also kept secure in the bag the whole time, because of the innovative little flap near the opening of the bags (see pic below), which helps create a spill-proof seal for dry snacks like our almonds and crackers. We also used the bags for sandwiches and sliced veggies, and loved how the bags always kept the contents from drying out and/or falling out of the bag.

I also like that they have a second hook-and-loop strip on the back, so you can just roll up a half-full bag and close it more tightly for a more snug fit. At first I didn’t know what the extra strip was for, but when necessity called, it was pretty self-explanatory from there. 🙂 You can see a video of what I’m talking about here.

Alright, so the bags work great, but what about washing and keeping them clean? I’m now in the habit of cleaning our ReUsies bags right when we get home (or I try!) since it’s easier and quicker than letting them sit for a while. Right when we get home, I flip them inside out and either dust off the crumbs, or I’ll run a wet rag over the nylon layer to clean away any leftover juices from fresh foods like our apple slices (see pic above). Then I just let them air dry in the dish rack. That’s it! Now, if we happen to have a larger mess to clean up (which is totally plausible with a toddler ;)), I’m glad to know that they’re also machine-washable and dishwasher safe.

If you’re looking for ways to help reduce your footprint by using reusable bags for your family’s lunches and snacks (and to save money at the same time!), ReUsies reusable sandwich and snack bags are a great option! Each bag has the potential to keep hundreds of bags out of our landfills and oceans. Be sure to follow ReUsies at the links below to stay updated on their latest deals and specials!

Facebook | Twitter | Blog

Ready To Try ReUsies Sandwich & Snack Bags?

You can purchase ReUsies bags right from their website for about $16 for a 2-pack like mine. They also sell 4-pack sets, and the sandwich and snack sizes separately, so you can mix and match for every member of the family. Their wide selection of colors and prints makes them great for everyone from toddlers to Mom and Dad. And right now if you order 4 or more bags, you’ll get FREE SHIPPING! Use code: “4ORMORE” at checkout.

ReUsies is also kind enough to sponsor a giveaway for one lucky Nature’s Nurture reader to win a 2-pack set of his/her own choosing! To enter for your chance to win, please use the Rafflecopter form below.

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Have you heard about this yet? Please tell me you have. Dr. Oz had a 5-page editorial in TIME magazine last week in which he completely attacks organic foods, farmer’s markets, and organic farms, and calls those who choose to utilize those avenues of sourcing their food as being “elitist” and “snooty” and “snobs.” Even though, just recently on his show, he was touting the health benefits of organic foods because they contain much smaller amounts of pesticide residue on them. Can you believe this guy? I stopped listening to him a long time ago, well before he had his own show, but this is definitely a new low, even for him. I’m left wondering who has bought him off, because he’s definitely sold out to someone!

Read my complete thoughts on this issue here:

Dear Dr. Oz, Why Are You Attacking Organic Food?

title: Dear Dr. Oz, Why Are You Attacking Organic Food?

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
You’ve heard of Dr. Oz, right? You know, the guy with his own show on TV, who was propelled to super-star doctor status by Oprah Winfrey! Yeah, that guy. Well, if you haven’t yet heard, he had a 5-page story in TIME magazine this week, title “What to Eat Now: The Anti Food Snob Diet.” in which it seems he’s finally showing his true colors…the idea that he’s sold out to large agricultural, bio-tech, and/or pharmaceutical companies.

In this TIME magazine piece (full story is available to subscribers, or read excerpts from Cornucopia Institute), Dr. Oz has come out against organic food, calling those who choose to feed their families organic, pesticide-free produce and pastured, grass-fed animal products as being “elitist,” “snooty,” and “not very democratic.” What?! Since when is food described as democratic or undemocratic? And why is it now “elitist” that families choose to source their food from farmer’s markets which utilize organic farming practices, free from pesticides, antibiotics, hormones, artificial colors, preservatives, and God knows what else?

And if that wasn’t enough, what really got me, was Dr. Oz’s “advice” on free-range chickens, and grass-fed, pastured cows. This one’s a doozy! Ready? I’ll let the Oz speak for himself here:

There’s no question that free-range chickens and grass-fed, pasture-dwelling cows lead happier — if not appreciably longer — lives than animals raised on factory farms. They are also kept free of hormones and antibiotics and are less likely to carry communicable bacteria like E. coli, which are common on crowded feedlots. If these things are important to you and you have the money to spend, then by all means opt for pricier organic meats.

Wow, let’s look at that again, “If these things are important to you and you have the money to spend, then by all means opt for pricier organic meats.” Umm, excuse me doc, “if these things are important to you?!” If? Uhh, yeah, if and when I do eat meat or eggs, I’d like for those products to be free from antibiotics, hormones, and oh yeah, E. coli would be nice too…definitely don’t want any E. coli with my morning omelette, thanks very much! And let’s not forget about those kind cows and chickens which have been raised to provide us with their healthy, nourishing meat, eggs, and milk – it’d be nice if they lived happy lives, since you know, they’re living creatures, with souls, and beating hearts?

What more? Oz also goes on to mention that,

Nutritionally speaking, there is little difference between the farmer’s-market bounty and the humble brick from the freezer case.

Yes, if you look at the nutrition facts on the back of a bag of frozen blueberries the nutritional profile would be very similar, if not identical, to that of a box of fresh blueberries from the local farmer’s market. But you know what those labels don’t show? They don’t show the level of pesticide residue left on those blueberries, after they’ve been picked, packed, shipped, and even washed. With all of the recent research on the negative effects of pesticides on our health, does this not matter at all when we’re comparing organic vs. non-organic foods?

Ok, so Dr. Oz – not a fan of organic foods and farmer’s markets. Got it. End of story, right?

I wish, but unfortunately, this story doesn’t end here. You see, bashing organic foods in a TIME magazine editorial piece is one thing; but, that one thing gets a bit complicated when you add to it another thing that happened just recently on Dr. Oz’s own show – he actually denounced the Stanford study, which found no difference between organic and non-organic food, by bringing up the very important point about pesticide residue. He even went on to draw connections between pesticides and ADD, compared pesticide residue on organic/non-organic produce, and provided some pointers on avoiding the foods with the highest level of pesticide residue.

Again, I’ll let the Oz man do the honors. Here, he speaks with a pediatrician about the dangers of pesticides and their effects on children. He also very enthusiastically tells us that the news reports about the Stanford study findings are wrong:

 

And here, he talks more about pesticide residue on produce, with comparisons between organic and conventional produce:

 

And finally, in this video, Oz acknowledges that organic produce is more expensive, but ensures his viewers that it’s worth it, especially if you focus on the produce with the highest amounts of pesticides:

So, let’s get this straight, Dr. Oz. One day, on your very own network television show, you advise us to eat organic foods becuase although, nutritionally, there’s no difference between them and conventional foods, they are still healthier and better for us; but then you come out with an editorial in TIME magazine this week, in which you’re taking everything back?

Wait, are you taking everything back? Or are you just kowtowing to some special interest groups in the agricultural, bio-tech, or pharmaceutical industries? Or maybe all three?

Of course, I can only speculate and can’t say for sure; but what I do know is that Dr. Oz is now officially an irrelevant voice in the food health and safety discussion. He cannot be trusted to give professional advice as a doctor, when he’s now advocating that toxic chemicals in our food (pesticides, antibiotics, hormones, etc.) are safe to eat, and that feeding your family as many organic, pesticide-free foods as you can is somehow “elitist” and “not very democratic.”

I’ve always thought Oz was very corporate and I stopped listening to him a long time ago (not that I did all that much in the first place), but this is a new low in hypocrisy and selling out. And like I said, he can’t be trusted. Not anymore. Not ever again. His credibility is shot and has gone down the drain, along with his dignity and self respect as a doctor.

The Hippocratic Oath includes the following statement:

I will prescribe regimens for the good of my patients according to my ability and my judgment and never do harm to anyone.

Dr. Oz, I’m afraid you’ve failed at this part of the oath. By downplaying the hazards of pesticides and other toxic chemicals in our food supply, and sidestepping the health benefits of organic and pastured foods, you are not looking out for the good of your patients. Instead, you’re providing them with false information about matters of health and well-being. Shame on you.

But I’m not worried, because my medical and health advice doesn’t come from millionaire TV-personality “doctors” placating to the needs and demands of sponsors, pharmaceutical companies, and the agricultural and bio-tech industries. No, I do my own research and look at all the facts when deciding on the best health regimen for my family. Here are just a few of our guidelines:

  • Organic is better, but not all “organic” is created equal. The best wholesome, nutritious foods are found at your local farmer’s markets and food coops, not the large supermarket chains and grocery stores.
  • Grass-fed, pastured beef and dairy is far superior to any factory-farmed animal products. Don’t fall for labeling gimmicks like “free-range” or “free-run,” which don’t restrict the use of drugs and other toxic ingredients. Look for the organic seal on these products (meat, milk, eggs, etc.).
  • Healthy, organic food can be more expensive, but not if you also cut out the unhealthy, processed foods, and make as many of your foods and snacks from scratch as possible.
  • Meat is expensive, especially ethically-raised, pastured meat. But you know what? We eat way too much meat in this country, and we could all benefit from cutting back our consumption. Many families eat meat at least once (if not twice) a day! We can afford to feed our families healthy meats, if we cut back to once a week, or even less.
  • No matter how our food is labeled at the grocery store, the healthiest foods will always be the ones you grow yourself (or from your local, trusted farmer). But if you’re unable to do so, then at least buy fresh, buy local, and buy organic when possible.

Thankfully, our family has it together with regards to our food and health choices. We understand the way our food system works and that we can’t rely on it if we want to actually provide our family with healthy, nutritious foods free from toxic chemicals. Unfortunately however, the majority of consumers are confused, afraid, or misinformed about these issues and look up to personalities like Dr. Oz to clear the fog for them. Many of them either know that they need to make some changes but don’t know where to start, or are completely clueless about these issues and not even trying to change at all.

Dr. Oz has taken a confusing situation and made it even worse. People are frustrated and tired of the constant battle between food and finances, and Dr. Oz is not helping the situation. Instead of telling everyone that all food is the same, and to just shut up and eat it, he could’ve directed readers to the Dirty Dozen and Clean Fifteen lists, which are meant to help families make informed decisions about when it’s necessary to buy organic foods, and when it’s ok to go the non-organic route. He could have emphasized the importance of knowing where our food comes from and how it’s made. He also could have stressed the cost-savings of buying fresh, local foods from farmer’s markets, when they’re in season.

But he didn’t do that. Instead, he chose to stay in line with what large corporations like Monsanto would do: promoting non-organic, processed foods filled with pesticides, GMOs, and a whole slew of other dangerous chemicals. Great job, Dr. Oz. I’m not sure you even deserve the title of “Dr.” anymore.

What do you think about Dr. Oz’s TIME magazine piece? Do you go out of your way to make sure the food your family is eating is as healthy and nutritionally balanced as possible, with lots of fresh, organic produce and pastured meat and dairy products? Do you think that makes you “snooty” or “elitist?” What would you say to Dr. Oz about his latest comments in TIME magazine? Share your thoughts with us in the comments, or head over to Dr. Oz’s Facebook page and tell him personally; it seems a lot of folks are giving him an earful…

title: Butternut Squash & Sweet Potato Soup

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Wow, it’s been like forever since I’ve posted a recipe on here, eh? I kinda miss it, actually. 🙂 And today’s recipe for this hearty butternut squash and sweet potato soup is definitely something to look forward to. You see, last night as I was making this, I posted a simple picture to my Instagram and Facebook pages:

I didn’t expect much response, but within minutes, friends and followers were liking, commenting, and asking to learn more about this weird soup recipe that includes an… apple?!

Yeah, that’s an apple. And in all honesty, it wasn’t my idea, but it was a pretty good one! I’d just picked up a beautiful 2 pound butternut squash and knew that I wanted to turn it into soup. And that I wanted all sorts of other goodies in that soup, because you know, soup is where you get to be creative and just throw a bunch of stuff in the pot, tasting as you go along. Oh, and I forgot to mention, I’ve never cooked with butternut squash before – is that weird? I feel like I’ve been living under a rock! 😉

Anyways, I found this recipe on AllRecipes.com and was already thinking of ways I can change it up, until I started reading some of the comments, and found that one person, “kiplee,” had already done a great job at that, so I pretty much used all of kiplee’s suggestions, with a few of my own changes. So, kiplee, if you’re out there reading this, thank you! 🙂

This is seriously, the best soup I’ve ever had – and that’s saying a lot, since I love soup! It’s nice and thick like a bisque, warm and hearty, and absolutely delicious! I knew I had to quickly write up the recipe and post it on the blog today to share with all of you!

Butternut Squash & Sweet Potato Soup
2013-09-28 00:37:09
Butternut squash and sweet potato are pureed with a sauteed mixture of ginger, garlic, onions, and a granny smith apple, for a warm, hearty, delicious bisque-like soup.
Write a review
Save Recipe
Print
Ingredients
  1. 1 (2 lb.) butternut squash, peeled, seeded, and cut into chunks
  2. 2 sweet potatoes, cut into chunks (I left the skin on, but washed really well)
  3. 2 carrots, peeled and chopped
  4. 2 stalks celery, chopped (I didn't have any and it was still delicious!)
  5. 1 onion, peeled and chopped
  6. 2 cloves garlic, minced
  7. 1 (3 in.) piece of ginger, peeled and finely chopped
  8. 1 apple, cored and chopped (I used granny smith and left the skin on)
  9. 2 tablespoons butter or oil
  10. 2 cups vegetable broth
  11. 2 1/2 cups water
  12. 1 teaspoon cinnamon
  13. 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg
  14. 1 1/2 teaspoon salt
  15. 1 teaspoon pepper
  16. 1 teaspoon cumin
  17. 1 teaspoon curry powder
  18. 1 teaspoon brown sugar
  19. 1/3 cup heavy cream (optional, but makes it more creamy)
Instructions
  1. Sautee the carrots, celery, onion, garlic, ginger, and apple in butter or oil until soft, about 10 minutes. Set aside.
  2. Add squash and sweet potato to a large pot and cover in broth and water.
  3. Bring to a boil, then add sauteed mixture to the pot and simmer on medium heat until all vegetables are soft.
  4. Add cinnamon, nutmeg, salt, pepper, cumin, and curry, and stir to mix well.
  5. Turn heat to low, and add brown sugar and mix well.
  6. Blend with an immersion blender (or put into a regular blender in batches) and puree until almost smooth.
  7. Optionally add the cream and stir until soup has changed color.
  8. Serve with crusty bread and a salad.
By Sarah UmmYusuf

title: Naturally Soft Laundry with Woolzies Dryer Balls {Review & Giveaway}

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
I’ve written a few posts already on how to make your laundry routine more natural and eco-friendly:

  • Homemade Liquid Laundry Detergent
  • Homemade Powdered Laundry Detergent
  • Natural Ways to Freshen Your Laundry

And today, I have another awesome laundry post about a new, natural way to soften your laundry, without the use of any chemicals or dryer sheets – have you seen what’s in those things?

Up until now, my laundry drying routine has been very basic: we line-dry as much as possible during the warmer months, but we do have to crank up the dryer during the cold, winter months. As I’ve talked about in my post on naturally freshening your laundry, all I do is add some vinegar to the wash cycle (to help soften), and use a homemade dryer sheet in the dryer (mainly for fragrance).

All has been working out very well for us, except for two things:

  • our towels and linens could definitely be a little softer
  • we occasionally have issues with static, especially on Mr. Nurture’s jersey shorts and pants

I’d come across a few ideas to help with these issues, none of which I was completely comfortable with using: rolled up aluminum foil balls, plastic dryer balls, tennis balls, etc. None of them seemed like a good idea – rolling up balls of aluminum foil over an over again, only to throw them out later just didn’t sit well with me; plastic dryer balls are made of… well, plastic (or worse, PVC!); and tennis balls just seem like they’d be loud and obnoxious!

Woolzies Dryer Balls Review

I pretty much decided that I had to live with slightly less-than-soft laundry, and a small bit of static on our clothes. That is until I was able to try out these Woolzies dryer balls! Woolzies are handmade wool dryer balls that soften your laundry naturally, and without the use of any chemicals. They also:

  • Save time and energy by cutting down drying time
  • Help reduce static and wrinkles
  • PVC-free and won’t fall apart or melt
  • Hypo-allergenic and safe for those with sensitivities to wool
  • Last for hundreds and hundreds of loads (500 loads or more!)

The set consists of 6 wool balls, shipped in a long package. The dryer balls are very soft to the touch and give in to a slight bit of pressure when squeezed. They smell like…nothing. And I love it!

After using Woolzies dryer balls for a couple months, I can honestly say that I love these things! They do in fact reduce drying time, and our clothes do seem to be less wrinkled when they come out of the dryer; but my main concern was the static and the softness of our linens and towels, and Woolzies has totally helped in those areas as well. Another bonus that I noticed is that they seem to fluff up our thicker linens and towels so that they’re not all rolled up into each other by the end of the drying cycle.

They’re also not nearly as loud as I thought they would be. Yes, there’s 6 balls bouncing around in your dryer, but they’re very soft and quiet and I hardly even noticed them. The only thing that was kind of a peeve was trying to fish out all 6 balls from one laundry load so I could use them for the next load. It takes just an extra minute between loads, but it’s well worth it, considering the other benefits. And after the last load, I just throw them back in the dryer, where they wait for the next laundry day.

Don’t mind a certain little toddler’s hand in the pic ;-)

If you’re looking for another way to make your laundry routine more green and eco-friendly, Woolzies Dryer Balls is a great place to start! Be sure to follow Woolzies at the links below to keep up with their latest deals and specials!

Website | Facebook | Twitter

Woolzies Dryer Balls can be purchased online through their website (Worldwide shipping!) or on Amazon. They’re about $35 for a set of 6 dryer balls that will last for over 500 loads.

title: Ditch The Detergent with a SmartKlean Laundry Ball {Review & Giveaway}

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
I’m so excited to bring you today’s sponsor, but first, let’s talk about laundry, shall we? One of the very first things I did when I started my journey to a greener, more eco-friendly lifestyle, was change up my laundry routine. I went from using commercial laundry detergents, fabric softeners, and dryer sheets, to making homemade liquid laundry detergent, powdered detergent, and using natural products to freshen our laundry.

This has worked for us for the past couple years, but one issue has come up that a few readers have voiced their concerns over:

  • The homemade laundry detergents both use borax, which may cause problems for those with skin sensitivities.

Yes, even though borax is a natural product and considered completely safe, it can still be problematic for people with sensitive skin. And since our kiddo, Monkey, has recently developed some moderate eczema on his arms, I’ve gone into “Mama Bear” mode trying to protect my little one from anything that may cause his eczema to flare up.

In my search for borax-free homemade laundry detergents, I came across a unique idea – a detergent-free laundry ball. That’s right, a laundry ball that washes your clothes without the use of any detergents whatsoever! I was completely intrigued and just had to try it for myself, so I contacted SmartKlean and they sent me one of their non-detergent laundry balls to try.

What Are SmartKlean Laundry Balls?

SmartKlean laundry balls are an innovative, new way to do laundry without the use of any harsh chemicals that are harmful to our health and the environment. Each ball contains special mineral ceramic beads that perform different functions. When they come into contact with water, they form oxygenated water. The water molecules are then fragmented into smaller sizes, enabling them to penetrate deep into the fabric to push out any dirt, grime, or odors.

  • Economical – Effectively washes 365 loads of laundry without using any soap or detergents. Replaces fabric softener and dryer sheets. Helps to conserve water and energy.
  • People-Friendly – Safe for the whole family! The active components inside are derived from Earth minerals and are formulated to leave zero residues behind. Ideal for sensitive skin.
  • Earth-Friendly – Leaves no trace in our aquatic ecosystems. With its extensive lifespan, it also reduces packaging waste in our landfills. Biodegradable ceramics and recyclable enclosure. BPA and PVC-free.

SmartKlean Laundry Balls Review

SmartKlean sent me one of their laundry balls and their new non-toxic stain remover to try.

I’ll admit. At first, I was a bit skeptical. I mean, how was a little green ball supposed to clean our laundry without using any type of detergent whatsoever? Even after I read more about how it works, and it all seemed logical, I still couldn’t wrap my head around it. The only way to really find out was to try it.

I’ve used it in both a top loader and a front loader, with great results!

I’ve been using the laundry ball exclusively for the past 2 months, and I’m so pleased with the results! Who knew clothes could still get clean without detergent? I sure as heck didn’t. The laundry ball is so easy to use. You just put your clothes in the washer, throw the ball in with them, and turn on the machine as normal. Only thing is that you can only use cold water, which is fine with me since that’s what we use anyways. I love quick and easy our laundry routine is now. No measuring, no pouring, no making sure all the detergent residue has rinsed out of our clothes and washer. This laundry ball is awesome, and it just works!

With an 18 month old in tow, there’s no shortage of food stains and dirt marks on his (and my) clothes, and I’m actually quite impressed with how well the SmartKlean laundry ball gets those stains out. I was happy to learn that I can still use baking soda and vinegar along with the laundry ball to help fight stains and soften the clothes. I did get to use the SmartKlean stain remover on one of Monkey’s pajama shirts, which had an unfortunate meeting with some spaghetti sauce. I wet the stain, rubbed the stain remover on the spot until it lathered, then threw it in the wash with his other clothes. It came out completely clean and stain-free – very impressive!

The only thing I haven’t washed with the laundry ball is Monkey’s cloth diapers. I guess I’ve been too afraid of the idea, but with my constant issues of detergent building up on the diapers and having to strip them regularly, I’m becoming more open to the idea. After some research, it seems a few others have tested it on their cloth diapers with much success. Only thing to remember is that you can’t use hot water with the laundry ball. Reviews of using SmartKlean laundry ball with cloth diapers can be found here and here.

Some Things To Keep In Mind

  • Stains: Although the laundry ball does a great job of cleaning colors and whites, it doesn’t contain any optical brighteners and won’t remove stubborn stains. You need to pretreat either with their non-toxic stain remover, or check out some their DIY tips here, here, and here. You could also pour some peroxide in the detergent dispenser to help whiten whites.
  • Scents: The laundry ball does not contain any scent and will not leave your clothes smelling like anything other than “clean.” However, you can use essential oils in the wash cycle (put a few drops into a cup of water and pour into detergent dispenser), or during the drying cycle (like my homemade dryer sheets).
  • Maintenance: For best results, place the laundry ball in the sun for 1-2 hours every 30 washes (approx.) in order to fully dry and recharge the laundry ball’s mineral ceramics. Do not exceed 2 hours as too much heat may damage the enclosure.
  • Usage: You must use cold water, and the laundry ball works better with a smaller load, which allows the ball to move around and agitate better. Before the first use, it’s recommended that you give your washer a good cleaning.

With these things in mind, I’m completely in love with the SmartKlean laundry ball. It gets the job done with no chemicals or toxins polluting our homes, bodies, or the environment. Be sure to follow SmartKlean at the links below to keep up with their latest news and green living tips!

Website | Facebook | Twitter

Ready To Try SmartKlean Laundry Balls?

You can purchase a SmartKlean laundry ball directly from their website for about $45. Remember that one laundry ball will last for 365 loads, so that comes to about $0.13 a load! For a price comparison between the laundry ball and commercial detergents, click here. Also, beware of counterfeit products being sold on Amazon and eBay, as SmartKlean doesn’t sell on those sites.

SmartKlean has also graciously offered to sponsor a giveaway for one lucky Nature’s Nurture reader to win one (1) laundry ball and one (1) non-toxic stain remover! To enter for your chance to win, please use the Rafflecopter form below.

title: #TinyTipTues 31: How To Ripen Bananas

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Happy Tuesday, everyone! Hope everyone made it through the crazy weekend in one piece and your week is off to a great start!

Today’s tip is about bananas. Yes, even though it’s almost December, I’m still buying bananas fairly regularly – I know, shame on me! Hey, we’ve all got our weaknesses… 🙂

Last week, the bananas were pretty unripe, and I remembered reading about ways to ripen bananas a while ago. The one that kept popping up was placing them in a bag with another fruit to help speed up the process…

Well, it definitely works! If you place your bananas into a brown paper bag along with an apple, within a couple of days your bananas will be nice and yellow, and ready to eat!

The reason this works is because apples give off ethylene gas, which hastens the ripening process. Other ethylene producing fruits include avocados, peaches and pears, but I think apples are mainly used because they give off the most gas. Also, make sure to fold the top of the bag down to help keep the air inside, and place it somewhere that’s on the warmer side, since cool temperatures tend to slow down the ripening process.

Oh, and it also works for plantains too, but it takes much longer (up to 2 or 3 weeks!) before they’ve completely ripened.

Cool, huh? I love when I hear about a cool tip like this one, and then I finally get to put it to good use when I actually need it! 🙂

title: Natural Homemade Anti-Itch Remedies

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Photo: Spyros Papaspyropoulos on Flickr

Although Winter technically doesn’t start for another month, it sure doesn’t feel that way here in Toronto – the temps today dipped into the negatives, it snowed for all of five minutes, and the slight breeze was not making things any better! Unfortunately, along with winter, comes the dry, itchy skin that is characteristic of eczema. There are many factors that contribute to eczema flare-ups, but for Yusuf and myself, it’s the cold, dry winters that get us all itchy and scratchy.

Yusuf has it especially bad and is scratching his poor little arms raw. 🙁 I initially went for the calamine lotion – an old favorite of my mom’s when we were growing up – but it wasn’t helping at all and I wanted to find something (or a series of things) to try that were natural and preferably homemade.

Well, I came across a whole bunch of great ideas for homemade anti-itch remedies and thought I’d share them with you! The ones I’m using on Yusuf are baking soda in the bath water, aloe vera gel, and oatmeal baths. And of course, lots and lots of moisturizer – especially right after baths, when his skin is still slightly damp.

What I’ve realized is not only is it important to treat the itch, but I needed to prevent the conditions that are causing the itching in the first place – dry, dehydrated skin. Thankfully, now that we alternate between baking soda and oatmeal baths, and apply a natural aloe vera gel (like this one) throughout the day, Yusuf’s skin is starting to calm down, and the itching seems to have died down a bit.

And from here, we just have to keep up with maintenance, and get through this winter! We also use these wonderful hard lotion bars from MadeOn Skin Care, which really help to seal in the moisture and keep it from drying out. I reviewed their lotion bars a while back, and you can read that review here: MadeOn Skin Care.

 

Here’s a list of some easy, homemade anti-itch remedies to calm down the itch:

  • Baking Soda – Make a compress by adding 1/3 cup of baking soda to a gallon of water, then soak a wash cloth in the solution, and apply to the itch. Alternately, you can make a paste of 1/2 cup baking soda, 1/8 cup water, and a teaspoon of salt, and apply it directly to the skin. Note: This should not be used on broken skin. For a widespread itch, add 1 cup baking soda to your bathwater and soak for 30-60 minutes.
  • Banana Peel – The inside of a banana peel can be used to treat many skin conditions, itches included. Simply cut off a piece of ripe banana peel a few inches long, and rub it on the itchy skin for a couple minutes, several times a day. This works best for bug bites and stings.
  • Oatmeal – Add 1 or 2 cups of finely ground oatmeal to your warm bath water and soak in the tub for about 10 minutes. The fats in oatmeal act as lubricants and create a gelatinous residue on your skin helping to lock in moisture and combat dryness. Make sure the oats are finely ground to a powder, otherwise they will be too heavy and just sink to the bottom of the tub.
  • Epsom Salts – Mix a big handful of epsom salts into your warm bath water and soak in it for as long as you like. Epsom salts have antibacterial qualities and promote healing.
  • Vinegar – Add 1 cup of white vinegar to your bath water and soak for as long as you like. Vinegar is a natural disinfectant and its acidity helps cool the skin and combat the itch. You can also make a really easy anti-itch rub using just raw apple cider vinegar and water – recipe can be found here.
  • Aloe Vera – Used mainly for burns, aloe vera is also a very good anti-itch treatment since the same its anti-inflammatory properties also work on itchy skin! Either snap off a leaf, slice it down the middle, and rub the gel on your skin, or you can purchase a natural aloe vera gel and apply it liberally to the skin several times a day.
  • Bath Oil – An easy homemade bath oil can be made by mixing 1-2 tablespoons of olive oil into a tall glass of milk. Apply all over the body and let it sit for 10 minutes, then have a bath in lukewarm water and dry your skin off gently.
  • Lemon – A natural anesthetic and anti-inflammatory, lemon juice has been used as an anti-itch treatment for hundreds of years. Apply the juice directly to the itch and let it air dry.
  • Herbal Compress – Basil, mint, and thyme have anesthetic and anti-inflammatory properties to help numb the itch and reduce inflammation. Make a tea with either of these herbs by adding 1/2 to 1 ounce of dried leaves into a pint of boiling water. Cover and let it cool, and then strain it, dip a wash cloth into the tea and apply as a compress to affected areas.
  • Herbal Salve – You can make (or purchase) your own homemade anti-itch salve from all natural ingredients! A great recipe is here.

*Please note: If your itching persists, gets worse, or spreads to other areas, then seek professional medical advice.

Do you suffer from dry, itchy skin caused by eczema or other skin conditions? What are your tried and true remedies?

title: Natural Sore Throat and Cough Remedy

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
It’s almost winter, and you know what that means! Well, besides snowmen and days off, winter unfortunately also means the height of the cold and flu season. Earlier this week, I shared with you natural ways to prevent and treat the common cold, and today I want to share a wonderful recipe I came across for a natural sore throat and cough remedy – probably my two least favorite cold symptoms.

Though, thankfully, we don’t get sick too often in our house, there’s always that one time that everyone is sick and it feels like the worst bug has gotten your entire family! But this bug was different. It wasn’t just the runny nose, the congestion, or the sinus pressure getting us down. It was the sore, scratchy throat, and the dry, hacking cough that came along with it! You know the one that makes it impossible to speak three words in a row without breaking out into a coughing frenzy?

Yeah, that one… Anyways, while my in-laws were sipping on the commercial cough syrups and meds, and hubby was just toughing it out on his own, I quickly went online to search for a homemade alternative to cough syrup.

I found this recipe from Good Food Matters – I loved that it was such an easy recipe and that I already had everything on hand to make it right away! 

Natural Sore Throat and Cough Remedy

I used almost the exact same recipe, except that I also added some cinnamon and garlic to the mixture, used fresh ginger instead of ground, and cut down the water (or you could even cut out the water completely, if you want).

Natural Sore Throat & Cough Remedy
2013-10-02 21:16:15
The healing powers of raw honey, cider vinegar, and traditional spices come together to make this super potent and powerful alternative to commercial cough syrups.
Write a review
Save Recipe
Print
Ingredients
  1. 1 tablespoon raw apple cider vinegar
  2. 1 tablespoon water
  3. 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper
  4. 1 teaspoon fresh grated ginger (or 1/4 teaspoon ground)
  5. 1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon
  6. 1 clove garlic, grated (or 1/4 teaspoon powder)
  7. 1 tablespoon raw honey, melted
  8. small glass jar with lid
Instructions
  1. If raw honey is hard, melt it using the double-boiler method, by putting it in a small glass bowl and placing it in a larger container filled with hot water. Do NOT melt it in microwave or on stovetop!
  2. In small glass jar, add apple cider vinegar and water.
  3. Add cayenne, ginger, cinnamon, and garlic. Cover jar and shake vigorously to combine.
  4. Add melted honey, and shake again to combine well.
  5. Shake well before use. Take 1-2 tablespoons as needed. No need to refrigerate unless making larger batches that will last longer than 2-3 days.
By Sarah UmmYusuf
Adapted from Good Food Matters
Adapted from Good Food Matters
Nature's Nurture http://naturesnurtureblog.com/
Wordpress Recipe Plugin by Recipe Card

 
3.1.09

 

More About The Ingredients

Each ingredient has its own wonderfully beneficial qualities:

  • Cayenne – reduces the sensation of pain, thins mucus, increases blood flow, and clears congestion.
  • Ginger – anti-inflammatory, relieves and suppresses coughing, and warms and energizes the body.
  • Cinnamon – anti-inflammatory, anti-fungal, and warms the body.
  • Garlic – antiviral, antibacterial, and helps support the immune system.
  • Apple Cider Vinegar – antibacterial, antiviral, antiseptic, and promotes healing.
  • Raw Honey – anti-viral, anti-bacterial, coats the throat, and contains beneficial enzymes to protect against infection.

The Results

I took two spoonfuls right after I made it, and within about 15-20 minutes, I was feeling a whole lot better! My throat still felt a bit scratchy, but it didn’t feel nearly as dry, and my cough had subsided quite a bit! I took another spoonful before going to bed, which helped pull me through the night.

And for the next few days, I took 1-2 spoonfuls 2-3 times a day, and was feeling much better by the end of the week. It’s definitely a bit spicy (although I like spicy), but the warming sensation on my irritated throat felt really soothing!

Some Helpful Tips

  • The cayenne and ginger in this recipe make it a pretty spicy syrup, so it’s not for the faint of heart (or for young children). You can either reduce (or eliminate) these ingredients, or try diluting the syrup with a little more water.
  • As with all products that contain honey, this should not be given to infants under 1 year because of the risk of botulism.
  • Using fresh ginger and garlic are best since the juice and oils contain most of the health benefits, but ground or powdered would work as well.
  • Make sure both your honey and cider vinegar are raw so that they have all the good, healing vitamins and enzymes.
  • If you’re making a single batch, you can store it at room temperature and use it up in 2-3 days. If you’re going to double or triple the recipe, and won’t finish it within 2-3 days, then it should be stored in the fridge. Although, it’s best to make up a new batch every few days to keep the ingredients nice and potent.

Have you ever tried a homemade cough remedy before? What’s your go-to treatment when the cold/flu season hits?

title: Natural Ways To Prevent & Treat The Common Cold

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
It’s that time of year again – the time of coughs, colds, sniffling, and sneezing. Nobody likes to get sick, and whether we get sick every year or just occasionally, the cold and flu season is a fact of life. Unfortunately, too many of us wait until it’s too late to try to heal ourselves. The truth of the matter is that there is no scientific cure for the common cold. Lots of rest and fluids is usually what the doctor orders. But the first step is prevention, and boosting our body’s natural immune system through natural means can give it the strength it needs to fight back at the first sign of infection.

This year I’m especially on alert because Monkey is 18 months old and pretty much has a life of his own now! 😉 When we go out to the store or the park, he’s off running around, doing his thing, and playing with other kids. It’s not the same as last year when we was bundled up in the carrier, close to mama, where no germs could get to him! So we’ve been taking a few extra measures to boost up our immunity this year, and I thought I’d share some of these ideas with you.

What’s working for our family is mainly increasing our intake of healthy, immune-boosting foods with high levels of vitamin C and zinc, like oranges, broccoli, and spinach (we have a nice, big green smoothie almost everyday!). We’re also taking local, raw honey in our tea almost everyday, and making sure to stay hydrated throughout the day. Also, at the very first sign of a cold, we make sure to start taking some echinacea; and if we’re too late and we’ve already caught something, our first line of defense is taking zinc lozenges, which help to shorten the duration and severity of symptoms of the common cold.

title: Natural Pain Relief from Noxicare {Review & Giveaway – 2 Winners!}

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Although we make most of our home and body care products at home, every once in a while, there’s a product or two that we’d just rather buy either from our local store or online. One of those products has been a topical pain relief cream for my joints and muscles (but mostly my joints). For as long as I can remember, I’ve always had very weak joints, especially on my left side. My ankles, knees, and elbows have always been very sensitive to any pressure or stress on the joints.

I was very fortunate to try out this natural pain relief cream from Noxicare. My main concerns with trying out pain relief creams, aside from the actual ingredients list, are the smell, the way it feels on the skin (ie: greasiness, etc.), and the cost.

Noxicare’s natural pain relief cream uses all natural ingredients and combines 7 of the world’s most potent natural pain relievers to alleviate inflammation, muscle aches, and nerve pain, with no known side effects, and without a prescription:

  • Turmeric: one of the powerful healers found in nature, recognized for its anti-inflammatory properties.
  • Willow Bark: has been used to treat pain and inflammation since the time of Ancient Egypt and Greece.
  • Ginger: helps alleviate muscle strains, arthritis and rheumatism, and is a catalyst for improving the effectiveness of other herbs.
  • Holy Basil: properties include anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antibacterial and antiviral.
  • Rosemary Extract: has served a variety of purposes including topical use for joint or musculoskeletal pain.
  • Alpha Lipoic Acids: antioxidants used to treating diabetic neuropathy and increasing blood flow to the nerves.
  • Boswellia Extract: an anti-inflammatory used to treat arthritis and joint pain.

Sounds good to me! All natural ingredients, that I can pronounce, and that I’ve actually heard of! Since that part was out of the way, I was ready to finally test out this natural pain relief cream on my achey joints and muscles.

 

I used the cream on my ankle, which had been hurting more than usual for the past several weeks. I guess I must have stepped on it wrong without realizing it, and I was having trouble sitting on my feet, as I like to do when I’m curled up on the couch. I applied the cream on my ankle three times a day for a week, and honestly, after the first application, I already noticed a difference in the way my ankle felt. It wasn’t a huge difference, but there was definitely a decrease in the pain I was feeling. By the end of that week, my ankle felt exceptionally better – I couldn’t believe this stuff was actually working!

Next, I tried the cream on my upper back and neck area, where a lot of stress and tension builds up overtime. I rubbed the cream on my neck and shoulders every night for about 5 nights, and I’d say the cream definitely gave my neck massage the extra kick of relief I’ve been looking for.

I love the way this cream feels on the skin. It’s not greasy at all, it goes on smooth, and gets absorbed right into the skin. Another huge plus with this natural pain relief cream is that it’s odorless! Yes, completely 100% odorless, unlike some of those other over-the-counter creams out there. And the price? Not so bad… For a 3.5 oz tube, you’ll pay about $27, but remember that a little goes a long way, so that tube could last a pretty long time, depending on how often and how much of it you use. (My tube was only 1.5 oz and I still have about half of it left!)

title: #TinyTipTues 30: Wash Your Blender The Easy Way!

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Happy Tuesday, dear friends! Hope all is well in your neck of the woods! 🙂 The weather is really starting to dip into the lower temps here, and winter is well on it’s way – so excited!

 

In case you haven’t heard yet, I’m now contributing to Healthy Planet Canada‘s new healthy living blog! Healthy Planet is actually my local organic store (they have 7 locations + a couple more soon!), and I was more than honored when they asked me to begin contributing to their blog. So every week, twice a week, I’ll be writing for them about green, healthy living, and eco-friendly topics! And don’t worry, you won’t miss a thing (as long as you’re subscribed to my weekly newsletter, or following me on Facebook), because I’m posting excerpts of my posts right here on Nature’s Nurture, which will lead you over to Healthy Planet’s blog for the complete article.

Also, my “Blogiversary” Giveaway Celebration is back and will continue through to the end of the year! So be sure to check every Wednesday for my latest giveaway! This week, we’re giving away a copy of my new favorite ebook, Meal Planning Made Simple, by my friend, Merissa, from Little House Living. This book has been a lifesaver and has helped me really get my kitchen running the way it was meant to be – quickly, efficiently, and most importantly, stress-free! Click the photo to the right for my complete review and to enter for your chance to win a free copy!

And now for our Tiny Tip of the week!

We make lots of smoothies around here – everyday actually. So there’s no shortage of dirty blenders around here, and when you use the blender that often, two things happen: 1- your blender manages to find a permanent home on your already over-crowded kitchen counter; and 2- you develop a hatred for cleaning the blender (who wants to keep disassembling and reassembling that thing on a daily basis?!). So, I came across this post on LifeHacker a few weeks ago and have been using this tip ever since!

After you’ve emptied your blender, just give it a quick rinse, then fill it about 1/3 of the way up with warm water and a few drops of dish soap. Put the cover back on blend away for 10-15 seconds, until the soapy water gets frothy and reaches the top. For extra scrubbing power, you can throw in a few ice cubes to help scrape down the sides.

Brilliant? I believe so! 🙂

Do you have any tips to share for cleaning your kitchen appliances? Please share!

It’s Tiny Tip Tuesday!

Now for the blog hop! If you missed last week’s party, head on over to check out some of those awesome tips!

Here are this week’s featured links:

The #1 Link:

Homemade Citrus Infused Vinegar by My Merry Messy Life

Sara from My Merry Messy Life shared this super easy recipe for making citrus-infused vinegar to use in your homemade cleaners. It’s great if you love using vinegar to clean your home but can’t stand the smell of it. Takes 2 weeks to make up a batch, so get your started now!

My Favorite Link:

Thanksgiving Crockpot Recipes by Practical Stewardship

Sonja from Practical Stewardship shared a great list of easy Thanksgiving recipes for the crockpot! I love using my crockpot – it’s one of my most used appliances, but never thought it could help in big family dinners like Thanksgiving. Check out the great recipes she has to share!

title: What Does “All Natural” Really Mean?

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
With the growing movement of families across the world going “green,” becoming more health conscious, and seeking more information about where exactly their foods and products come from, there’s been an increased push from large corporations and marketing companies to find new ways profit from this new trend. Unfortunately, more often than not, these corporations and marketers hold their own financial interests well above the health and well being of the consumer.

Walk down the aisles of any major chain supermarket, and you’re bound to come across several products (or entire lines of products) marketed as being “natural” or “all natural” or even “100% natural.” But what exactly do those labels even mean? And how, if at all, are they regulated? You’d be surprised, but those labels don’t really much, when it comes to the quality of our food!
